origination.corpname: University of Michigan. University Planner's Office.

did.unittitle: University Planner's Office (University of Michigan) records 1950-1987
did.abstract: Adjunct of University Architect's Office responsible for campus development and upkeep. Records include correspondence with architects, meeting minutes, reports, photographs and architectural drawings relating to campus planning and renovation; including landscaping, zoning, parking, lighting, walkways and signage.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The University Planner's Office (Donor no. 5582) makes periodic additions to the records.

accessrestrict.p: The records are open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Board of Regents of the University of Michigan

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, University Planner's Office (University of Michigan) Records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The University Planner's Office has historically reported to Plant Extension and is an offshoot of the University Architect's Office. The responsibilities of the two offices have often overlapped and their respective responsibilities for campus development and upkeep are intertwined.

The University Architect's Office was established in 1957 within the Plant Service Department, with Lynn W. Fry the first person to hold the title of University Architect. In 1964 John D. Telfer, formerly the Assistant to the University Architect, became the university's first University Planner. Telfer served in this position until 1968. Frederick W. Mayer then assumed the position and continues to oversee the University Planner's Office to this date.

As stated above, the responsibilities of the University Planner are tangential to those of the University Architect, both being the natural result of an expanding, growing university community. The University Architect's Office devotes the bulk of its time to advising and serving as liaison between architects and the university community on construction and renovation projects. The role of the University Planner's Office is akin to that of a civil engineer and is concerned with the issues that accompany campus development, including zoning, street construction, signage, landscaping, exterior lighting, and parking.
For further information regarding building projects at the University of Michigan, the researcher should also consult the records of the University Architect's Office.

scopecontent.p: The records of the University Planner's Office consist of eight linear feet of correspondence, memoranda, meeting minutes, reports, architectural drawings, and photographs spanning the years 1950 to 1987. The records document the role of the University Planner's Office in campus planning on the University of Michigan campuses and in conjunction with the City of Ann Arbor. Records include correspondence with architects, meeting minutes, reports, photographs and architectural drawings relating to campus planning and renovation; including landscaping, zoning, parking, lighting, walkways and signage.
The records are arranged alphabetically in one series of Topical Files.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.corpname: University of Michigan. University Planner's Office.
controlaccess.subject: Construction industry--Michigan--Ann Arbor.
Architecture--Michigan--Ann Arbor.
Landscape architecture.

controlaccess.head: Subjects - Visual Materials:
controlaccess.corpname: University of Michigan. University Planner's Office.

scopecontent.p: The Topical Files (8 linear ft) generally concern issues that arise from the construction of a building or other campus development. These issues are broad-ranging and include parking lots and structures, changes in traffic patterns, exterior lighting, bicycle paths and bicycle racks, recreation areas, signage, pedestrian bridges and walkways, zoning issues, and landscaping. As the University Planner works in close contact with the University Architect, this record group also includes material concerning the numerous building projects on the three university campuses.
